newsitem.title: UK: Safeway sales growth slows, wary on profits.
newsitem.headline: Safeway sales growth slows, wary on profits.

text.p: British supermarket retailer Safeway Plc said on Friday that same store sales in the five weeks to January 4 were up 5.2 percent but that over the first 16 weeks of the second half growth slowed to a 4.5 percent rise.
The store chain, which holds a 7.8 percent share of Britain's grocery market, said if the slowdown in sales continued, "profits for the remaining eight weeks of the current year might be affected."

Safeway, which ranks third to market leader Tesco Plc and J. Sainsbury Plc, said slipping inflation, which fell in the early weeks of the new year from a slim 1.1 percent gain in the five weeks to January 4, could also be a factor.

Safeway said that volume growth achieved was strong and its marketing and customer service continued to be successful, adding it was confident it could deliver "a further year of solid profit growth."

Safeway's statement comes just a week after Sainsbury shocked the market when it said investment to boost sales, which gained to a 4.4 percent rise over the key Christmas trading period, would hurt profits.

Tesco, which pipped Sainsbury off the top slot just over a year ago as it launched a loyalty card, managed to maintain sales growth at 7.5 percent over the Christmas period, while the fourth largest chain, ASDA does not report on trading.
